						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Richard Jewell</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">For other people named Richard Jewell, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Jewell_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Jewell (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Richard Jewell (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox person (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox person</a>
</p><p><b>Richard Allensworth Jewell</b> (December 17, 1962 &#8211; August 29, 2007) was an American police officer who, while working as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Security_guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Security guard (page does not exist)">security guard</a> for <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_College" title="Piedmont College">Piedmont College</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-piedmontcollege_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-piedmontcollege-1">[1]</a></sup> became known in connection with the <a href="/wiki/Centennial_Olympic_Park_bombing" title="Centennial Olympic Park bombing">Centennial Olympic Park bombing</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics" title="1996 Summer Olympics">1996 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlanta,_Georgia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlanta, Georgia (page does not exist)">Atlanta, Georgia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>. Discovering a backpack filled with three pipe bombs on the park grounds, Jewell alerted police and helped to evacuate the area before the bomb exploded, saving many people from injury or death.  Initially hailed by the media as a hero, Jewell was later considered a <a href="/wiki/Suspect" title="Suspect">suspect</a>. Jewell's case is considered an example of the damage that can be done by reporting based on unreliable or incomplete information.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite never being officially charged, he underwent a "<a href="/wiki/Trial_by_media" title="Trial by media">trial by media</a>" with great toll on his personal and professional life.  Eventually he was completely exonerated and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eric_Robert_Rudolph&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eric Robert Rudolph (page does not exist)">Eric Robert Rudolph</a> was later found to have been the bomber.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> In 2006, Governor <a href="/wiki/Sonny_Perdue" title="Sonny Perdue">Sonny Perdue</a> publicly thanked Jewell on behalf of <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">the state of Georgia</a> for saving the lives of those at the Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-hero_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hero-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bombing">Bombing</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Centennial_Olympic_Park" title="Centennial Olympic Park">Centennial Olympic Park</a> was designed as the "town square" of the Olympics, and thousands of spectators had gathered for a late <a href="/wiki/Concert" title="Concert">concert</a> and merrymaking. Sometime after midnight, July 27, 1996, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eric_Robert_Rudolph&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eric Robert Rudolph (page does not exist)">Eric Robert Rudolph</a>, a  <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorist</a> who would later bomb a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homosexuality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homosexuality (page does not exist)">gay</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nightclub&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nightclub (page does not exist)">nightclub</a> and two <a href="/wiki/Abortion_clinic" title="Abortion clinic">abortion clinics</a>, planted a green <a href="/wiki/Backpack" title="Backpack">backpack</a> containing a shrapnel-laden <a href="/wiki/Pipe_bomb" title="Pipe bomb">pipe bomb</a> underneath a bench. Jewell, in his capacity as a security guard, discovered the bag and alerted <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Bureau_of_Investigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georgia Bureau of Investigation (page does not exist)">Georgia Bureau of Investigation</a> officers; this discovery was nine minutes before Rudolph called <a href="/wiki/9-1-1" title="9-1-1">9-1-1</a> to deliver a warning. Jewell and other security guards began clearing the immediate area so that a <a href="/wiki/Bomb_disposal" title="Bomb disposal">bomb squad</a> could investigate the suspicious package. The bomb exploded 13 minutes later, killing Alice Hawthorne and injuring over one hundred others. A cameraman also died of a heart attack while running to cover the incident.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Investigation_and_the_media">Investigation and the media</span></h2>
<p>Early news reports lauded Jewell as a <a href="/wiki/Hero" title="Hero">hero</a> for helping to evacuate the area after he spotted the suspicious package. Three days later, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlanta_Journal-Constitution" title="The Atlanta Journal-Constitution">The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</a></i> revealed that the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">FBI</a> was treating him as a possible suspect, based largely on a "lone bomber" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Offender_profiling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Offender profiling (page does not exist)">criminal profile</a>. For the next several weeks, the news media focused aggressively on him as the presumed culprit, labeling him with the ambiguous term "<a href="/wiki/Person_of_interest" title="Person of interest">person of interest</a>", sifting through his life to match a leaked "lone bomber" profile that the FBI had used. The media, to varying degrees, portrayed Jewell as a failed law enforcement officer who may have planted the bomb so he could "find" it and be a hero.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two of the bombing victims filed lawsuits against Jewell on the basis of this reporting. In a reference to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theodore_Kaczynski&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theodore Kaczynski (page does not exist)">Unabomber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jay_Leno" title="Jay Leno">Jay Leno</a> called him the "Una-<a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/doofus" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:doofus">doofus</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Other references include "Una-Bubba," <sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> and (of his mother) "Una-Mama."  Jewell was never officially charged, but the FBI thoroughly and publicly searched his home twice, questioned his associates, investigated his background, and maintained twenty-four hour surveillance of him. The pressure only began to ease after Jewell's attorneys hired an ex-FBI agent to administer a <a href="/wiki/Polygraph" title="Polygraph">polygraph</a> which Jewell reportedly passed.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 1996, the investigating <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney" title="United States Attorney">US Attorney</a>, Kent Alexander, in an extremely unusual act, sent Jewell a letter formally clearing him, stating "based on the evidence developed to date ... Richard Jewell is not considered a target of the federal criminal investigation into the bombing on July 27, 1996, at Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Libel_cases">Libel cases</span></h2>
<p>After his exoneration, Jewell filed a series of <a href="/wiki/Lawsuit" title="Lawsuit">lawsuits</a> against the media outlets which he claimed had <a href="/wiki/Defamation" title="Defamation">libeled</a> him, primarily <a href="/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlanta_Journal-Constitution" title="The Atlanta Journal-Constitution">The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</a>,</i> and insisted on a formal apology from them. L. Lin Wood was the lead attorney in all of Jewell's libel cases.<sup id="cite_ref-piedmontcollege_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-piedmontcollege-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CNN_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CBS_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, Jewell said the lawsuits were not about money, and that the vast majority of the settlements went to lawyers or taxes. He said the lawsuits were about clearing his name.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Richard_Jewell_v._Piedmont_College"><i>Richard Jewell v. Piedmont College</i></span></h3>
<p>Jewell filed suit against his former employer <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_College" title="Piedmont College">Piedmont College</a>, Piedmont College President <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raymond_Cleere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raymond Cleere (page does not exist)">Raymond Cleere</a> and college spokesman Scott Rawles.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-9">[9]</a></sup> Jewell's attorneys contended that Cleere called the FBI and spoke to the Atlanta newspapers, providing them with false information on Jewell and his employment there as a security guard. Jewell's lawsuit accused Cleere of describing Jewell as a "badge-wearing zealot" who "would write epic police reports for minor infractions."<sup id="cite_ref-piedmontcollege_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-piedmontcollege-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Piedmont College settled for an undisclosed amount.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Richard_Jewell_v._NBC"><i>Richard Jewell v. NBC</i></span></h3>
<p>Jewell sued NBC News for this statement, made by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Brokaw" title="Tom Brokaw">Tom Brokaw</a>: "The speculation is that the FBI is close to making the case. They probably have enough to arrest him right now, probably enough to prosecute him, but you always want to have enough to convict him as well. There are still some holes in this case".<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Even though <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> stood by its story, the network agreed to pay Jewell $500,000.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Richard_Jewell_v._New_York_Post"><i>Richard Jewell v. New York Post</i></span></h3>
<p>On July 23, 1997, Jewell sued <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">The New York Post</a></i> for $15 million in damages and settled with the newspaper for an undisclosed amount.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Richard_Jewell_v._Cox_Enterprises_.28d.b.a._Atlanta_Journal-Constitution.29"><i>Richard Jewell v. Cox Enterprises (d.b.a. Atlanta Journal-Constitution)</i></span></h3>
<p>Jewell also sued the <i>Atlanta Journal-Constitution</i> newspaper. According to Jewell, the paper's headline, <i>FBI suspects 'hero' guard may have planted bomb</i>, "pretty much started the whirlwind".<sup id="cite_ref-CBS_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-10">[10]</a></sup> In one article, the <i>Atlanta Journal</i> compared Richard Jewell's case to that of serial killer <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Williams" title="Wayne Williams">Wayne Williams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The newspaper was the only defendant that did not settle with Jewell. The lawsuit remained pending for several years, after having been considered at one time by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_Georgia_(U.S._state)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supreme Court of Georgia (U.S. state) (page does not exist)">Supreme Court of Georgia</a>, and had become an important part of <a href="/wiki/Case_law" title="Case law" class="mw-redirect">case law</a> regarding whether journalists could be forced to reveal their sources. The case was dismissed by Judge John R. Mather in December 2007, four months after Jewell's death. The paper claimed this was proof of the accuracy of their coverage but the dismissal came because the plaintiff passed away.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="CNN">CNN</span></h3>
<p>Although <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> settled with Jewell for an undisclosed monetary amount, CNN maintained its coverage was fair and accurate.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Aftermath">Aftermath</span></h2>
<p>In July 1997, <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General" title="United States Attorney General">U.S. Attorney General</a> <a href="/wiki/Janet_Reno" title="Janet Reno">Janet Reno</a>, prompted by a reporter's question at her regular weekly news conference, expressed regret over the FBI's leak to the news media that led to the widespread presumption of his guilt, and apologized outright, saying, "I'm very sorry it happened. I think we owe him an apology. I regret the leak."<sup id="cite_ref-Reno_to_Jewell_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reno_to_Jewell-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in 1997, Jewell made public appearances in film and television. He appeared in <a href="/wiki/Michael_Moore" title="Michael Moore">Michael Moore</a>'s 1997 film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Big_One_(film)" title="The Big One (film)">The Big One</a></i>. He had a cameo in the September 27, 1997 episode of <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>, in which he punched <a href="/wiki/Will_Ferrell" title="Will Ferrell">Will Ferrell</a> (who was in character as Janet Reno), and jokingly fended off suggestions that he was responsible for the deaths of <a href="/wiki/Mother_Teresa" title="Mother Teresa">Mother Teresa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diana,_Princess_of_Wales" title="Diana, Princess of Wales">Princess Diana</a>.
</p><p>On July 4, 2001, Jewell was honored as the Grand Marshal of the <a href="/wiki/Carmel,_Indiana" title="Carmel, Indiana">Carmel, Indiana's Independence Day Parade</a>. Jewell was chosen in keeping with the parade's theme of "Unsung Heroes."<sup id="cite_ref-Carmelfest_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carmelfest-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 13, 2005, Jewell was exonerated completely when <a href="/wiki/Eric_Rudolph" title="Eric Rudolph">Eric Rudolph</a> pled guilty to carrying out the bombing attack at the Centennial Olympic Park, as well as three other attacks across the South. On August 1, 2006, Georgia governor <a href="/wiki/Sonny_Perdue" title="Sonny Perdue">Sonny Perdue</a> honored Jewell for his rescue efforts during the attack.<sup id="cite_ref-Jewell_Finally_Honored_As_A_Hero_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jewell_Finally_Honored_As_A_Hero-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewell had worked various law enforcement jobs, including as a police officer in <a href="/wiki/Pendergrass,_Georgia" title="Pendergrass, Georgia">Pendergrass, Georgia</a>. He worked as a sheriff's deputy in <a href="/wiki/Meriwether_County,_Georgia" title="Meriwether County, Georgia">Meriwether County, Georgia</a> until his death. He also gave speeches at colleges.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_2-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewell died August 29, 2007, from natural causes at the age of 44. He was suffering from severe heart disease, kidney disease, and diabetes.<sup id="cite_ref-hero_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hero-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
